name: Citalopram (Celexa)
summary: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used for depression and certain anxiety disorders.
description: Citalopram is an SSRI antidepressant indicated for major depressive disorder (MDD) and sometimes used off-label for anxiety disorders such as panic disorder and social anxiety disorder. It is a racemic mixture of R- and S-enantiomers, with the S-enantiomer (escitalopram) being primarily responsible for its antidepressant effect. While effective and generally well tolerated, citalopram carries a dose-dependent risk of QT prolongation, which limits its maximum recommended dose.

sections.text: Selectively inhibits the serotonin transporter (SERT), increasing serotonin concentrations in the synaptic cleft, which improves mood and anxiety symptoms over time.

adult.titrate: Increase to 40 mg/day after at least 1 week if needed and tolerated
adult.max: 40 mg/day; 20 mg/day if age ≥60, hepatic impairment, or CYP2C19 poor metabolizer

sections.renal_impairment: No adjustment in mild/moderate; caution in severe impairment

sections.text: Initial improvement may be seen in 1–2 weeks; full therapeutic effect often takes 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Antidepressants increase the risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults.
other: Dose-dependent QT prolongation risk; avoid doses above recommended maximum
Caution in patients with cardiac disease, electrolyte disturbances, or other QT-prolonging drugs

items: ECG in at-risk patients or high doses

sections.pregnancy: Category C; weigh risks and benefits
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant for irritability or poor feeding
sections.pediatrics: Not FDA approved; caution with dosing
sections.geriatrics: Max 20 mg/day due to QT risk

sections.text: Gradually decrease dose over 1–2 weeks (or longer) to minimize withdrawal symptoms.

items: Avoid abrupt discontinuation to reduce withdrawal risk
If inadequate response, consider dose increase or switch to another antidepressant
Escitalopram is the S-enantiomer and may be better tolerated
